page.title: 08Agriculture in North Yorks
page.content: There are very few permanant pastures which have escaped the plough. These are now used for stock rearing & horses,however the destruction of hedges has now tailed off & conservation is an important issue. At various times of the year farmers bring their flocks down from the moors for dipping,tupping & shearing,a sight popular with the tourists. One must not be in hurry as cows are moved daily for milking,too & from the one local dairy farm. The moors are heavily infested with bracken & this harbours ticks which infect sheep & grouse. Aerial spraying to control the growth of bracken has been tried but has yet to be proved effective. The Lord of the manor owns the shooting rights for which pheasant & other game birds are locally reared.
